uk.ac.macaulay.util
Class GISRaster<T>

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.macaulay.util.Table<T>
      uk.ac.macaulay.util.GISRaster<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
GISKeyedRaster
public class GISRaster<T>
extends Table<T>

A GISRaster is a Table that also includes georeferencing information and a 'no data' value or cells specifically stated as containing no data. The georeferencing information pertains to the 'origin' of the table, which is the co-ordinate of the bottom-left corner of the cell in the bottom row, leftmost column of the table. The atXY... methods are preferred for accessing table contents, and these methods are overloaded to provide access using co-ordinates on the georeferenced scale.

Author:
Gary Polhill

getNoDataValue

public T getNoDataValue()
The 'no data' value is an entry in the table that indicates no data are available for that cell. The value is null by default, but that does not mean that all cells have data. The atXYNoData(double, double) method (or the int equivalent) may be used to assert that there are no data for a cell without assigning it a value indicating as much. Cell entries are also null by default, which also means no data have been given.

Returns:
The 'no data' value

atXY

public T atXY(double x,
              double y)
Return a value for a georeferenced co-ordinate. A value is return regardless of whether the co-ordinate corresponds to an entry in the table: all values outside the table are 'no data' values (null by default). If you want an exception to be thrown if the co-ordinate is out of range, use atXY(convertX(x), convertY(y)).

Parameters:
x - Eastings
y - Northings
Returns:
Entry in the table or 'no data' value

atXY

public T atXY(int x,
              int y)
Return a value for an (x, y) co-ordinate in the table. If x and y are outside the table's range, then an exception will be thrown.

Overrides:
atXY in class Table<T>
Parameters:
x -
y -
Returns:
Entry in the table for the specified co-ordinate
See Also:
Table.atXY(int, int)

atXFlipY

public T atXFlipY(int x,
                  int y)
Return a value for the co-ordinate in the table. The y-axis is 'flipped' and is equal to the row number.

atXY

                 double y,
                 T value)

atXYNoData

public void atXYNoData(double x,
                       double y)
Stipulate that there is no data in the cell corresponding to the georeferenced co-ordinate. (No exception is thrown if the co-ordinate is out of range; if you want one, do atXYNoData(convert(x), convert(y)).)

Parameters:
x -
y -

atXYNoData

public void atXYNoData(int x,
                       int y)
Stipulate that there is no data in the specified cell. This will throw an exception if the cell co-ordinates are out of bounds, and set the current entry in that cell to null, deleting any entry therein.

Parameters:
x -
y -

isAtXYNoData

public boolean isAtXYNoData(double x,
                            double y)
Check whether there is no data for a specified georeference. This will not throw an exception if the georeference is out of the table's bounds, but will instead return true. If you want an exception to be thrown in this case, do isAtXYNoData(convert(x), convert(y)).

Parameters:
x -
y -
Returns:
true if the cell in the table corresponding to the georeference has a 'no data' entry, or the georeference is out of bounds.

isAtXYNoData

public boolean isAtXYNoData(int x,
                            int y)

Check whether a cell has a 'no data' entry. An exception is thrown if the cell is out of bounds. A cell has a 'no data' entry if any of the following apply:

  • it is null
  • it is equal to the 'no data' value
  • it has been stipulated to have no data via a call to atXYNoData(double, double) (or the int equivalent) and no subsequent call to atXY(double, double) (or the int equivalent) has given the cell a value.

Parameters:
x -
y -
Returns:
true if there is no data for the given cell.

asGISKeyedRaster

public GISKeyedRaster<T> asGISKeyedRaster(java.util.Map<T,java.awt.Color> key)
Convert the GISRaster into a GISKeyedRaster using a key mapping entries to colours.

Parameters:
key - The key (aka legend) mapping entries in the table to colours
Returns:
A GISKeyedRaster

Returns:
